Journal.Title: Bulletin of environmental contamination and toxicology

Article.ArticleTitle: Wheat Cultivar Growth, Biochemical, Physiological and Yield Attributes Response to Combined Exposure to Tropospheric Ozone, Particulate Matter Deposition and Ascorbic Acid Application.

AbstractText: In the present study wheat (Triticum aestivum) cultivar HD 2967 was exposed to ambient and elevated levels of O<sub>3</sub> and PM deposition, with and without exogenous application of ascorbic acid (AA). Cultivar HD 2967 exposed to eight treatments in free air O<sub>3</sub> enrichment facility and the assessed results showed that wheat cultivar, growth, biochemical, physiological and yield attributes were variably but adversely affected by combined exposure to O<sub>3</sub> and PM deposition. PM deposition clogged stomata and enhanced leaf temperature. However, plants exposed to O<sub>3</sub> and PM deposition and treated with AA exhibited less reduction in yield as compared to plants exposed to O<sub>3</sub> and PM deposition without AA treatment. The decline in grain yield of HD 2967 due to combined exposure of O<sub>3</sub> and PM deposition were in the range of 4%-17%. AA spray partially mitigated ozone and PM deposition adverse impact and enhanced wheat yield by 16%.
